page.title: 05Place-names around Pencombe
page.content: Many of the modern farm place-names are recognisable in their 14th c. form. Pencombe comes from OE{pen}and {cumb}meaning enclosure in the valley of the 'muddy' Lodon. 14th c. Castell appears to have been an area now part of the Nash with a rectangular moated site, Fishpool Croft, and Tump Hopyard, possibly the site of an earlier minor motte. Collier's Coppice, the charcoal burners' coppice; Sparrington, an enclosure in a wood; Wootton, the homestead by a wood; and Hennerwood, the wood on the high ridge, all indicate woodland. Hegdon may be hay hill, Grendon, a green valley and Hundreds Meadow is on the hundred boundary. Church House was Churchyard in 1344 and legend tells that Bodenham buried its dead from the plague there. Few names appear to be Welsh despite Pencombe's proximity.
